lexUnit.name: pursuer.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: somebody who follows another person in order to catch or attack

sentence.text: If the pursuers of Robert the Bruce had been women , they 'd have known that cobwebs come overnight .

Thus Realism was able to make a quick conquest by importing a neat and powerful idea of science and showing how an economics-style analysis of nation states as pursuers of national interest scored high as science .
Richard Pitman stole a quick look round to assess the closeness of his nearest pursuer -- at least twenty lengths -- and shortened the reins to keep Crisp together for the final draining half mile .
Singlewood , 17 , ran into the courtyard of Durham Castle in a desperate bid to shake off his pursuer .
As he turned away the second of his pursuers appeared on the pavement in front of him , drawing its hand from his pocket .
Desperately , the Doctor tries a series of random landings in the hope of eluding their pursuers .
Clearly prey need to be both sprinters over short distances and marathon runners over longer ones , to be able to defend themselves against both types of pursuers .
The freezing sleet , half snow , half rain-wrapped ice , made the pavements like skating rinks underfoot and blew into the eyes of the pursuers .
Obviously this was a ruse to throw would-be pursuers off the scent .
They could hear the squealing roars of their pursuers over the tumult of their mounts ' hoofs .
I recall imitating a stunt performed by the obscure Buffalo Bill Jnr in a Poverty Kow serial , when he outwitted his pursuers by swinging at speed from saddle into tree .
The fourth managed to elude his pursuers by escaping into a bog where no horse could follow .
Hard on his heels came the pursuit , and at the head of the pursuers was Richard .
We zigzagged swiftly here and there over Europe to throw off the pursuers and finally returned to this house , which he had taken upon his first arrival in England .
Wily and bold , he and his companion threw their pursuer off their track by entering a lodging-house in Edmonton Street and leaving by the back-gate into Curzon Square .
